title: Glossary of Key Terms
overview: Consolidated index of 100+ definitions used throughout the specification

content.text: This glossary provides quick reference to key terms and definitions appearing across all 30 sections of the STRATUM specification. Terms are organized alphabetically with cross-references to defining sections.

items.definition: Connection between abstract element and concrete realization. Defined: Definition 2.22 (§2.5). See also: Groundedness (G4, §4.4)
Propagation of element changes across dependencies. Defined: Definition 2.26 (§2.6). Rules: CASCADE-1, CASCADE-N (§6)
Assertion about specification elements with priority levels. Defined: Definition 2.16 (§2.4). Categories: Traceability, Completeness, Consistency
Link between elements with delta semantics. Defined: Definition 2.11 (§2.3). Types: traces_to, implements, depends_on, satisfies
Atomic unit of specification with identity, type, layer, properties, metadata. Defined: Definition 2.1 (§2.1)
Level of abstraction containing elements. Defined: Definition 2.4 (§2.2). Tiers: motivation → logical → realization → grounding
Formal document with elements, layers, dependencies, constraints, bindings, cascades, reasoning. Defined: Definition 2.9 (§2.5)
Element classification with variance rules. Defined: Definition 5.1 (§5). Variance: strict, covariant, contravariant
Conditions ensuring specification validity. Rules: WF-ID through WF-ACYCLIC-HARD (§3)
Every element traces back to root in motivation tier. Formula: ∀ e ∈ E. ∃ e' ∈ E. root(e') ∧ reachable(e, e', traces_to)
All error-level constraints satisfied. Formula: ∀ c ∈ ErrorConstraints(S). S ⊨ c
No contradictory properties between elements. Formula: ∀ e₁, e₂ ∈ E. ¬contradiction(e₁, e₂)
Every leaf element has binding to physical reality. Formula: ∀ e ∈ E. leaf(e) → bound(e)
Impact of changes is computable. Formula: ∀ δ. impact(S, δ) is decidable
Dependencies flow from concrete to abstract (except traces_to). Formula: ∀ d ∈ D. pos(layer(d.src)) ≥ pos(layer(d.tgt)) ∨ d.δ = traces_to
Type relation where τ₁ <: τ₂ implies Container(τ₁) <: Container(τ₂). Used for outputs/return types. Rule: COV-SUBTYPE (§5)
Type relation where τ₁ <: τ₂ implies Container(τ₂) <: Container(τ₁). Used for inputs/parameters. Rule: CONTRA-SUBTYPE (§5)
No variance applied; types must match exactly. Used for invariant contexts. Rule: STRICT-SUBTYPE (§5)
Partial order on types enabling substitution. Reflexive, transitive, respects layer tier boundaries. Rules: REFL, TRANS (§5)
Quantifier-Free Linear Integer/Real Arithmetic with Equality and Uninterpreted Functions. Decidable constraint language used for predicates. SMT-LIB standard fragment. Definition 2.12 (§2)
Assertion that element e has type τ in context Γ. Notation: Γ ⊢ e : τ. Rules: ELEM-TYPE, LAYER-TYPE (§6)
Establish binding from abstract element to concrete realization with evidence and proof. Operation 7.5 (§7)
Measure of specification completeness w.r.t. concern. Returns [0, 1]. Operation 7.4 (§7)
Compute structural differences between specifications. Returns added, removed, modified elements. Operation 7.6 (§7)
Compute cascade propagation of change δ. Returns affected elements. Operation 7.7 (§7)
Combine specifications, resolving conflicts via constraint priorities. Returns merged specification. Operation 7.8 (§7)
Find all elements reachable from e via traces_to dependencies. Operation 7.2 (§7)
Check all well-formedness conditions and constraint satisfactions. Operation 7.1 (§7). Returns Result with violations
Single-step cascade computation: δ triggers immediate dependent changes
Multi-step cascade: transitive closure of CASCADE-1
Constraint satisfaction check: c.φ(elements, deps) evaluates to ⊤
Specification validation: All WF-* rules hold AND all constraints satisfied
Well-formedness judgment for specification. Prerequisite for SPEC-VALID
Base case: root element (motivation tier, no incoming traces_to)
Inductive step: follow traces_to dependencies backward to root
Maps elements to monotonically-decreasing impact magnitude. Limits cascade propagation. Defined: §18 (Formal Attenuation Properties)
Lifecycle: unverified → verified → trusted with evidence trail. State machine: §14 (Binding Verification)
Concurrent data structure enabling merge without coordination. Used for concurrency semantics §13. Papers: Shapiro et al. 2011
Last-Writer-Wins Element Set CRDT. Resolves concurrent add/remove conflicts by timestamp. Definition 21.3 (§21). Used for element merging in specification synchronization
Controlled changes to specification structure. Categories: backward_compatible, forward_compatible, breaking. §16
Assertions about specification behavior over time using LTL/TLA+. Properties: □ (always), ◇ (eventually), U (until). §22
Architectural boundaries between motivation-logical-realization-grounding. Enforced by coherence (G6). §2.2, §30

CRDT deletion marker preserving causal history. Prevents resurrection of deleted elements in concurrent environments. Used in CRDT garbage collection (Theorem 17.1-17.3) with logical timestamps for semantic preservation
Formal spec decidable w.r.t. all constraints. If valid manually, algorithm accepts. Proof by SMT solver (Z3/Dafny)
Well-formedness and constraint satisfaction are decidable problems. Proof: reduction to first-order logic with QE
CRDT garbage collection preserves observable semantics. Proof using logical time stamps and tombstone analysis
Type safety maintained across reduction steps. If Γ ⊢ e : τ and e →β e' then Γ ⊢ e' : τ. Standard proof technique
Non-stuck evaluation: Well-formed specifications don't reach undefined states. Proof by contradiction using reduction semantics
Type soundness: If ⊢ S then S satisfies all well-formedness conditions. Proof by structural induction on type derivations
ISO 26262 levels A-D for safety-critical automotive systems. ASIL-D highest. Maps to SIL 3-4 (IEC 61508)
FAA guidance for software in airborne systems. Covers planning, development, testing, certification. 71 objectives with STRATUM mapping
Tool qualification for avionics software tools. Guidance for qualifying compilers, analyzers, generators. §18
Bottom-up hazard analysis: element → failure modes → effects → mitigations. Integrated with STRATUM §26.3
Top-down hazard analysis: system hazard → causes → gate logic → basic events. Integrated via STRATUM elements §26.3
Functional Safety standard for E/E/PE systems. SIL 1-4 levels. Generic framework; STRATUM harmonizes via attenuation §18
Maps hazards → UCAs → safety constraints → STRATUM constraints → formal properties. Artifact: §17
Control-theoretic hazard analysis by Leveson. Models control structures, UCAs, scenarios. Integrated §26.2
Control action that, in a given context, can lead to hazard. Types: not provided, provided incorrectly, wrong timing, stopped too soon, wrong direction. §26.2
Interactive theorem prover for mechanized proofs. STRATUM proof templates in §19 for soundness/preservation
Configuration of constraint vocabulary and semantic properties for specific domain. Examples: Software Systems, Manufacturing, Healthcare. §8
Method to add custom constraint packs and semantic rules. Composition via union with priority resolution. §9
Functional programming language with dependent types for mechanized proofs. Alternative to Coq/TLA+. §19
Record: ⟨created, updated, version, status, actor, clock⟩. Enables audit trail and CRDT causality. Definition 2.2 (§2.1)
Element attribute: partial function NAME → VALUE. Type constraints per layer TYPE. Definition 2.1 (§2.1)
Formal specification language by Lamport for distributed systems. Used for temporal properties (§22) and proof templates (§19)
ACTOR → ℕ mapping for causality tracking in concurrent systems. Enables version vectors and CRDT commutativity. Definition 2.3 (§2.1)
TypeScript-first schema validation library. STRATUM reference implementation schemas. §11
